metadata.name: AD Groups Or Users Enumeration Using PowerShell - ScriptBlock
metadata.comment: Adversaries may attempt to find domain-level groups and permission settings. The knowledge of domain-level permission groups can help adversaries determine which groups exist and which users belong to a particular group. Adversaries may use this information to determine which users have elevated permissions, such as domain administrators.

batch.sql: SELECT * FROM script_activity WHERE time BETWEEN CURRENT_TIMESTAMP() - INTERVAL 24 HOUR AND CURRENT_TIMESTAMP() AND (lower(activity_id) = lower('1') AND (contains(lower(script.script_content.value), lower('get-adprincipalgroupmembership')) OR contains(lower(script.script_content.value), lower('get-aduser')) AND contains(lower(script.script_content.value), lower('-f ')) AND contains(lower(script.script_content.value), lower('-pr ')) AND contains(lower(script.script_content.value), lower('doesnotrequirepreauth'))))

output.summary: Adversaries may attempt to find domain-level groups and permission settings. The knowledge of domain-level permission groups can help adversaries determine which groups exist and which users belong to a particular group. Adversaries may use this information to determine which users have elevated permissions, such as domain administrators.
